title: 109_s3490
content: The Act is titled the "Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge Study Act" and includes findings related to the refuge. Congress finds that the Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to over 80 special-concern animal and plant species, including 6 endangered or threatened species such as the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, northeastern bulrush, and small whorled pogonia. Cherry Valley in northeastern Pennsylvania is habitat for numerous special-concern species, including the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, northeastern bulrush, small whorled pogonia, bald eagle, and Indiana bat. Additionally, Cherry Valley supports at least 79 species of national or regional concern. Cherry Valley in northeastern Pennsylvania provides habitat for special-concern species such as the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, northeastern bulrush, small whorled pogonia, bald eagle, and Indiana bat. It also supports at least 79 species of national or regional concern, including neotropical migratory birds like the Cerulean Warbler, Worm-eating Warbler, and Wood Thrush, as well as waterfowl such as the American Black Duck. The Cherry Valley watershed in northeastern Pennsylvania provides habitat for various special-concern species, including neotropical migratory birds like the Cerulean Warbler, Worm-eating Warbler, and Wood Thrush, as well as waterfowl such as the American Black Duck. Additionally, the area supports globally rare plants and anadromous fish species. The watershed encompasses a significant portion of the Kittatinny Ridge, an important migration route for birds of prey in the northeastern United States. The Cherry Valley watershed in northeastern Pennsylvania supports globally rare plants like the spreading globeflower and anadromous fish species. The Kittatinny Ridge, a crucial migration route for birds of prey in the northeastern United States, is home to various migratory raptor species including the bald eagle, golden eagle, and broad-winged hawk. The Kittatinny Ridge in northeastern Pennsylvania is a crucial migration route for birds of prey, including the bald eagle, golden eagle, and broad-winged hawk. It also features a segment of the Appalachian Trail and significant wildlife habitats in Cherry Valley, such as rare calcareous wetlands. Ongoing studies have shown high water quality in Cherry Creek. The Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania features significant wildlife habitats, including rare calcareous wetlands. Ongoing studies have confirmed the high water quality of Cherry Creek. Additionally, there are two federally-owned parcels of land adjacent to the area, potentially for inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. (8) 2 federally-owned parcels of land, including the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area and a 700-acre segment of the Appalachian Trail, are contiguous to the area for potential inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Public meetings have shown strong local support for the refuge over several years. Public meetings over several years have demonstrated strong local support for a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with area landowners, business leaders, and elected officials voicing enthusiasm. Numerous local communities and conservation entities also share complementary goals. Area landowners, business and community leaders, media, and elected officials have consistently shown support for a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Numerous local communities and conservation entities are actively working to protect Cherry Valley, along with State land management agencies and the National Park Service, as potential strong partners. Local entities, including landowners, are actively working to protect Cherry Valley and conserve wildlife habitat and farmland. They are potential strong partners for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Local landowners in Cherry Valley have put their land into conservation easements. Monroe County and Stroud Township in Pennsylvania have voter-approved funds for open space and land conservation. Several local landowners in Cherry Valley have placed their land in conservation easements. Voter-approved funds from Monroe County and Stroud Township in Pennsylvania have supported various conservation projects in the area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "map," "Secretary," and "Study Area." SEC. 4. STUDY OF REFUGE POTENTIAL AND FUTURE REFUGE LAND ACQUISITION. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Study Area for potential acquisition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, consulting with various stakeholders. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders to identify eligible land and determine boundaries for potential acquisition for a national wildlife refuge in the Study Area. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders to identify eligible land and determine boundaries for potential acquisition for a national wildlife refuge in the Study Area, including assessing suitability for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System and management in accordance with the policies of the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966. The Secretary will determine if the Study Area is suitable for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System and assess the conservation benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including preserving diverse populations of fish, wildlife, and plants. The establishment of Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge aims to preserve diverse populations of fish, wildlife, and plants, protect aquatic and wetland habitats, and provide opportunities for wildlife-dependent recreation and scientific research. The Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge aims to protect diverse species under the Endangered Species Act, enhance aquatic and wetland habitats, provide opportunities for wildlife-dependent recreation and research, and fulfill international obligations regarding fish and wildlife. Public participation and local views are also considered. The Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge aims to protect diverse species, enhance habitats, provide recreational opportunities, and fulfill international obligations. Public participation and local views are considered in land acquisition, limited to 30,000 acres. A report is due within one year. The Secretary of the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge will acquire up to 30,000 acres of land, water, and interests in the Study Area for refuge purposes. Within one year, a report detailing the study results will be submitted to the Senate and House committees. The Secretary of the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge will acquire land, water, and interests in the Study Area for refuge purposes. A report with a map identifying and prioritizing specific areas for acquisition will be submitted to Senate and House committees. The report will include a map identifying specific areas for acquisition by the Secretary for the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, along with a cost estimate for acquiring the land, water, and interests in the Study Area. The report will include a delineation of an acquisition boundary for the potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, a cost estimate for acquiring land, water, and interests in the Study Area, and an estimate of funds available from non-Federal sources for acquisition and management. The Secretary will determine land, water, and interests for refuge status in the Study Area, along with an estimate of funds available from non-Federal sources. $200,000 is authorized for the Secretary to carry out this section.
